case_name: Bombay Union of Journalists, Mrs. Aruna Mukherji and Mr. M. T. Thomas v. State of Bombay and Indian National Press, Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 497 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 497 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 10, 1960, of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 10 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 10 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellants are Bombay Union of Journalists, Mrs. Aruna Mukherji, and Mr. M. T. Thomas.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Union of Journalists which is the Trade Union registered under the Trade Unions Act, 1926, Mrs. Aruna Mukherji, and Mr. M. T. Thomas are appellants 1 to 3

facts.text: Respondents are State of Bombay (respondent No. 1) and Indian National Press, Bombay (Private Ltd. Co., respondent No. 2).

anchor.surface_text: and the State of Bombay, and the Indian National Press, Bombay, which is a Private Ltd. Co. are respondents 1 and 2 respectively in the present appeal.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 (Mrs. Aruna Mukherji) appointed on staff of second respondent on salary of Rs. 500 p.m. with effect from 1st January, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 2 was appointed on the staff of the second respondent on a salary of Rs. 500 p.m. with effect from 1st January, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 served with notice of termination of services on 30th November, 1957, effective from 1st December, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th November, 1957, she was served with -- notice of termination of her services with effect from 1st December, 1957.

facts.text: Notice to Appellant No. 2 recited that management in consultation with Editor decided to retrench her services.

anchor.surface_text: The notice recited the fact that the management in Consultation with the Editor had decided to retrench her services.

facts.text: Appellant No. 3 (Mr. M. T. Thomas) employed as Sub-Editor in Free Press Journal some time in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 3 Mr. Thomas who was employed as a Sub-Editor in the Free Press Journal some time in 1953,

facts.text: Appellant No. 3 served with notice of retrenchment dated 30th November, 1957, terminating services from 1st December, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: was similarly served with a notice of retrenchment dated the 30th November, 1957 by which his services were terminated as from the 1st December, 1957.

facts.text: Notices to appellants 2 and 3 stated retrenchment under section 3(2) of Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955, and paid salaries for three months in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: In both the notices the two appellants respectively were told that their services had been retrenched under section 3 (2) of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscel- laneous Provisions Act, 1955, and that in lieu of notice they would be paid their salaries for three months.

facts.text: Both appellants collected salaries for November 1957 and ceased to work for respondent No. 2 from 1st December, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellants collected their salaries for the month of November and ceased to work for respondent No. 2 as from the 1st December, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 wrote to Director-in-charge of second respondent on 3rd December, 1957, complaining of vindictiveness against appellants 2 and 3, demanding withdrawal of notices and reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that appellant No. 1 took up their cause on the 3rd December, 1957 and wrote to the Director-in-charge of the second respondent company complaining that the action taken by the 2nd respondent smacked of vindictiveness against appellants 2 and 3, and demanded that the notices issued should be withdrawn forthwith and they should be reinstated in their original posts.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 did not accede to the demand.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 did not accede the said demand thereupon,

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 moved Labour Commissioner of respondent No. 1 for action.

anchor.surface_text: appellant No. 1 moved the Labour Commissioner of respondent No. 1 for taking further action in the matter.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer intervened, called parties, discussions held, no settlement possible, submitted failure report under s. 12(4) on 15th April, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: At that stage, the Conciliation Officer intervened and called the parties before him. As a result of the discussion held before the Conciliation Officer, it was discovered that no settlement was possible, and so, the Conciliation Officer submitted a failure report under s. 12 (4) of the Act on the 15th April, 1958.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer opined no possibility of settlement due to parties' stands.

anchor.surface_text: In this report, the Conciliation Officer expressed his opinion that in view of the stand taken by the parties, there was no possibility of any settlement, and so, he was compelled to record a failure.

facts.text: Both parties filed statements before respondent No. 1 after failure report.

anchor.surface_text: After the matter was thus reported to respondent No. 1 by its Conciliation Officer, both the parties filed their res- pective statements before respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 considered statements and report, concluded no need to refer dispute to Tribunal under s. 12(5).

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 considered the said statements and the report submitted by the Conciliation Officer and came to the conclusion that it was not necessary to refer the dispute to a Tribunal under s. 12 (5) of the Act.

facts.text: Decision communicated by letter dated 1st July, 1958 from Dy. Secretary, Labour and Social Welfare Department of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was communicated to the appellants by the Dy. Secretary, Labour and Social Welfare Department of respondent No. 1 by his letter dated 1st July, 1958.

facts.text: Reasons in letter: termination is retrenchment, management willing to pay legal dues, not mala fide, vindictive or victimisation for trade union activities.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to set out the reasons given in this letter for not referring the dispute to the Tribunal. These reasons were set out in the letter in these terms The termination of services of Shrimati Aruna Mukherji and Shri M. T. Thomas a ppears to be an act of retrenchment on the part of the management for which the management is willing to pay all the legal dues to the retrenched persons and  (2) in effecting the said termination the management does not appear to have acted mala fide or vindictively not practised victimisation for trade union activities.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court for mandamus against respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then moved the Bombay High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of mandamus against respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Single Judge of Bombay High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition was heard by a single Judge of the said High Court and was ultimately dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants filed Letters Patent Appeal before Division Bench of Bombay High Court, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants challenged the correctness of the said decision by a Letters Patent Appeal before a Division Bench of the High Court. The Division Bench agreed with the view taken by the learned single Judge, and so, the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: No notice under s. 25F(c) served by respondent No. 2 on respondent No. 1 prior to termination of services of appellants 2 and 3. Common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that no notice had not been served by respondent No. 2 on respondent No. 1 as required by s. 25F(c) prior to the termination of services of appellants 2 & 3

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J. on December 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: December 19, 1963.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1960,

issues.text: The principal point of law which this appeal raises for our decision relates to the construction of section 25F(c) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The principal point of law which this appeal raises for our decision relates to the companystruction of section 25F c  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  No. 14

His contention is that just as s. 25F a  and  b  are both mandatory and constitute conditions precedent for valid retrenchment, so is s. 25F c

issues.text: Even if s.25F(c) constitutes a condition precedent, whether a writ of mandamus should be issued against respondent No. 1 to refer the dispute

anchor.surface_text: There is one more point which ought to be mentioned before we part with this appeal. Even if we had held that s. 25F c  constitutes a condition precedent, it would not have been easy to accept Mr. Bishan Narain's contention that a writ of mandamus should be issued against respondent No. 1.

arguments.claim: Appropriate government must refer if breach of mandatory provision like s.25F(c)

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that the appropriate Government is bound to refer an industrial dispute even though one of the points raised in the dispute is in regard to the contravention of a mandatory provision of the Act?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ditions precedent is obvious. These provisions have to be satisfied before a workman can be retrenched. The hardship resulting from retrenchment has b

arguments.court_reasoning: s.10(1) allows refusal even for s.25F breach if inexpedient, absent mala fides

holdings.text: A prima facie examination of the merits cannot be said to be foreign to the enquiry which the appropriate Government is entitled to make in dealing with a dispute under s. 10(1) read with s.12(5).

anchor.surface_text: This argument must be rejected, because when the appropriate Government considers the question as to whether ,a reference should be made under s. 12 5 , it has to act under s. 10 1  of the Act, and s. 10 1  confers discretion on the appropriate Government either to refer the dispute, or not to refer it, for industrial adjudication according as it is of the opinion that it is expedient to do so or not. In other words, in dealing with an industrial dispute in respect of which a failure report has been submitted under s. 12 4  the appropriate Government ultimately exercises its power under s 10 1 , subject to this that s. 12 5  imposes an obligation on it to record reasons for not making the reference when the dispute has gone through conciliation and a failure report has been made under s. 12 4 . This question has been considered by this Court in the case of the State of Bombay v. K. P. Krishnan Others  1 . The decision in that case clearly shows that when the appropriate Government considers the question as to whether any industrial dispute should be referred for adjudication- or not, it may consider, prima facie, the merits of the dispute and take into account other relevant considerations which would help it to decide whether making a reference would be expedient or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(5) read with s.10(1) confers discretion based on expediency, allowing prima facie merits review; supported by precedent in State of Bombay v. K.P. Krishnan; distinguishes final adjudication from prima facie view.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the argument that respondent No.1 did not consider the failure to comply with s.25F(c), as it construed the provision as directory per Rule 80.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain has then urged that the main point of controversy between the parties was in regard to the failure of respondent No. 2 to comply with the provisions of S. 25F c  of the Act and that has not been considered by respondent No. 1 while refusing to make a reference in the present case. Section 25F c  provides that no workman to which the said provision applies shall be retrenched by the employer until notice in the prescribed manner is served on the appropriate Government. It is common ground that no notice had not been served by respondent No. 2 on respondent No. 1 as required by s. 25F c  prior to the termination of services of appellants 2 & 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Govt's own Rule 80 treats s.25F(c) notice as post-retrenchment when wages paid in lieu under (a); no need for explicit mention; court not in appeal over reasons unless irrelevant.

holdings.text: s.25F(c) cannot be said to constitute a condition precedent which has to be fulfilled before retrenchment can be validly effected.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that s. 25F c  cannot be said to constitute a condition precedent which has to be fulfilled before retrenchment can be validly effected. In this connection, there is one more consideration which is relevant. We have already seen the requirement of s. 25F a . There is a proviso to s 25F a  which lays down that no such notice shall be necessary if the retrenchment is under an agreement which specifies a date for the termination of services.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes purpose: (a)(b) protect workman with notice/wages/compensation at retrenchment time; (c) informs govt post-retrenchment, esp. with wages in lieu under (a); consistent with Rule 80; negative form/'until' satisfied after; no precedent directly on point.

holdings.text: s.25F(c) is directory and not mandatory like clauses (a) and (b), which are conditions precedent.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the main point which has been strenuously argued before us by Mr. Bishan Narain with regard to the construction of s. 25F c . His contention is that just as s. 25F a  and  b  are both mandatory and constitute conditions precedent for valid retrenchment, so is s. 25F c  mandatory and a condition precedent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (a)(b) mandatory for workman protection at retrenchment; (c) different object - govt information; illogical pre-retrenchment when immediate retrenchment via wages in lieu; rules support post-notice.

holdings.text: Even if s.25F(c) constitutes a condition precedent, appropriate Government not bound to refer dispute; s.10(1) discretion persists unless mala fide.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical; s.10(1)/12(5) allows refusal even for s.25F breach if inexpedient; mandamus only for irrelevant grounds/mala fides; govt normally refers but not obligated.

anchor.surface_text: This argument must be rejected, because when the appropriate Government considers the question as to whether ,a reference should be made under s. 12 5 , it has to act under s. 10 1  of the Act, and s. 10 1  confers discretion on the appropriate Government either to refer the dispute, or not to refer it, for industrial adjudication according as it is of the opinion that it is expedient to do so or not. In other words, in dealing with an industrial dispute in respect of which a failure report has been submitted under s. 12 4  the appropriate Government ultimately exercises its power under s 10 1 , subject to this that s. 12 5  imposes an obligation on it to record reasons for not making the reference when the dispute has gone through conciliation and a failure report has been made under s. 12 4 . This question has been considered by this Court in the case of the State of Bombay v. K. P. Krishnan Others  1 . The decision in that case clearly shows that when the appropriate Government considers the question as to whether any industrial dispute should be referred for adjudication- or not, it may consider, prima facie, the merits of the dispute and take into account other relevant considerations which would help it to decide whether making a reference would be expedient or not.
The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain has then urged that the main point of controversy between the parties was in regard to the failure of respondent No. 2 to comply with the provisions of S. 25F c  of the Act and that has not been considered by respondent No. 1 while refusing to make a reference in the present case. Section 25F c  provides that no workman to which the said provision applies shall be retrenched by the employer until notice in the prescribed manner is served on the appropriate Government. It is common ground that no notice had not been served by respondent No. 2 on respondent No. 1 as required by s. 25F c  prior to the termination of services of appellants 2 & 3
The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that s. 25F c  cannot be said to constitute a condition precedent which has to be fulfilled before retrenchment can be validly effected. In this connection, there is one more consideration which is relevant. We have already seen the requirement of s. 25F a . There is a proviso to s 25F a  which lays down that no such notice shall be necessary if the retrenchment is under an agreement which specifies a date for the termination of services.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the main point which has been strenuously argued before us by Mr. Bishan Narain with regard to the construction of s. 25F c . His contention is that just as s. 25F a  and  b  are both mandatory and constitute conditions precedent for valid retrenchment, so is s. 25F c  mandatory and a condition precedent.
The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.
